docs.abstract: Fears of an overheated economy could prompt the Federal Reserve to cut short a recovery in which incomes have already struggled to gain traction.
docs.snippet: Fears of an overheated economy could prompt the Federal Reserve to cut short a recovery in which incomes have already struggled to gain traction.
docs.lead_paragraph: Corporate profits have rarely swept up a bigger share of the nation’s wealth, and workers have rarely shared a smaller one.

headline.main: Paychecks Lag as Profits Soar, and Prices Erode Wage Gains
headline.print_headline: Profits Swell, But Laborers See No Relief

docs.abstract: Amid a growing call for governments to rein in the use of the technology, Microsoft became the first tech giant to join the chorus.
docs.snippet: Amid a growing call for governments to rein in the use of the technology, Microsoft became the first tech giant to join the chorus.
docs.lead_paragraph: Microsoft on Friday became the first tech giant to join a growing call for regulations to limit the use of facial recognition technology.

headline.main: Microsoft Urges Congress to Regulate Use of Facial Recognition
headline.print_headline: Microsoft Urges Rules for Facial Recognition

docs.abstract: Mr. Sorrell and his new firm, S4 Capital, beat out the advertising giant, his former company, for the purchase of MediaMonks.
docs.snippet: Mr. Sorrell and his new firm, S4 Capital, beat out the advertising giant, his former company, for the purchase of MediaMonks.
docs.lead_paragraph: Martin Sorrell, the former chief executive of the advertising giant WPP who is now trying to build a new ad company, beat out his former employer for the purchase of a Dutch marketing firm on Tuesday, a move that WPP claimed could endanger millions of dollars in his stock awards.

headline.main: Martin Sorrell Beats WPP in Bidding War for Dutch Marketing Firm
headline.print_headline: Chief, Ousted By WPP, Thwarts It In Bid War

docs.abstract: The Information Commissioner’s Office said it was fining Facebook 500,000 pounds — the maximum allowed — for letting Cambridge Analytica harvest users’ information without their consent.
docs.snippet: The Information Commissioner’s Office said it was fining Facebook 500,000 pounds — the maximum allowed — for letting Cambridge Analytica harvest users’ information without their consent.
docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Facebook was hit with the maximum possible fine in Britain for allowing the political consulting firm Cambridge Analytica to harvest the information of millions of people without their consent, in what amounts to the social network’s first financial penalty since the data leak was revealed.

headline.main: Facebook Fined in U.K. Over Cambridge Analytica Leak
headline.print_headline: U.K. Fines Facebook For Misuse Of Data

byline.original: By Adam Satariano and Sheera Frenkel

docs.abstract: Facebook is working to spread its face-matching tools even as it faces heightened scrutiny from regulators and legislators in Europe and North America.
docs.snippet: Facebook is working to spread its face-matching tools even as it faces heightened scrutiny from regulators and legislators in Europe and North America.
docs.lead_paragraph: When Facebook rolled out facial recognition tools in the European Union this year, it promoted the technology as a way to help people safeguard their online identities.

headline.main: Facebook’s Push for Facial Recognition Prompts Privacy Alarms
headline.print_headline: Facebook Pores Over Its Prize Asset: Faces

docs.abstract: The lira’s plunge, exacerbated by a dispute with the U.S. over a detained pastor, has exposed growing economic pressures that some economists say could be near a breaking point.
docs.snippet: The lira’s plunge, exacerbated by a dispute with the U.S. over a detained pastor, has exposed growing economic pressures that some economists say could be near a breaking point.
docs.lead_paragraph: Turkish banks are pulling back on credit to consumers and businesses. Power plants have shut down because of the soaring cost of imported fuel. Building projects in Istanbul stand half finished after their backers ran out of money.

headline.main: Life in Turkey Now: Tough Talk, but Fears of Drug Shortages
headline.print_headline: Plunge in Lira Exposes Longtime Economic Pressures Building in Turkey

docs.abstract: After initial harassment allegations against the CBS chief, some board members reflexively defended Mr. Moonves. It took weeks for his support to fade.
docs.snippet: After initial harassment allegations against the CBS chief, some board members reflexively defended Mr. Moonves. It took weeks for his support to fade.
docs.lead_paragraph: On a Monday in late July, CBS’s board of directors convened a conference call to determine the fate of its chairman and chief executive, Leslie Moonves, who had been publicly accused of sexual harassment and assault.

headline.main: Threats and Deception: Why CBS’s Board Turned Against Leslie Moonves
headline.print_headline: Revelation of Moonves’s Deceit Was Last Straw for CBS Board

docs.abstract: Traditional plots of land are slowly becoming parts of bigger operations, eroding a way of life but enriching local residents and helping more Chinese people move into the modern world.
docs.snippet: Traditional plots of land are slowly becoming parts of bigger operations, eroding a way of life but enriching local residents and helping more Chinese people move into the modern world.
docs.lead_paragraph: SHANHUI, China — This village doesn’t change quickly. The ebb and flow of the planting and harvesting seasons still govern the lives of its 3,000 residents. Some rise at 3 a.m. to cook homemade tofu, a Shanhui specialty, over a coal-burning stove. Most homes remain topped by traditional Chinese tiled roofs, here crowned by carved dragon’s heads, as is local custom.

headline.main: China’s Small Farms Are Fading. The World May Benefit.
headline.print_headline: China’s Small Farms Are Fading. The World May Benefit.

docs.abstract: Sheera Frenkel, who writes about cybersecurity for The Times, explains how she safeguards her devices, and why passwords remain a weak link for more people.
docs.snippet: Sheera Frenkel, who writes about cybersecurity for The Times, explains how she safeguards her devices, and why passwords remain a weak link for more people.
docs.lead_paragraph: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? Sheera Frenkel, a technology reporter in San Francisco, discussed the tech she’s using.

headline.main: Setting Up Your Tech on the Assumption You’ll Be Hacked

docs.abstract: A remark by the F.D.A.’s chief about almonds and lactation has set off a seemingly existential debate about what milk is.
docs.snippet: A remark by the F.D.A.’s chief about almonds and lactation has set off a seemingly existential debate about what milk is.
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — No one can even agree on milk anymore.

headline.main: Got Milk? Or Was That Really a Plant Beverage?
